newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares extend gains, seen losing steam.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares extend gains, seen losing steam.

text.p: Polish shares rose for the sixth session running but analysts said the slightly stronger selling after price fixing showed the market losing steam on Friday and made it unclear if a significant growth trend would follow.
"It seems we now have a tug-of-war between buyers and sellers," said Krzysztof Rogalski, an analyst at Bank Staropolski SA brokerage.

Analysts said recent systematic gains in higher turnovers by several large-cap stocks was a good sign that could help return the market toward recent highs next week after its previous three weeks of stabilisation.

"Nothing had happened on the market for a long time so I think buying of some forgotten stocks could bring the market toward its latest (27-month, 14,282-point) high next week," said Artur Nagorka, a trader at Wood & Company.
The main market's all-share WIG index rose 2.9 percent to 13,597.4 points and turnover rose 15 percent to 119.8 million zlotys on both markets.

Staropolski's Rogalski said current buying was more speculative, pointing to Thursday's 5.2-percent surge by the parallel market of smaller stocks, and said a larger inflow of foreign capital to spur a big rise would only come later.
Analysts said BRE and Gorazdze, which rose in active trade by four and 3.1 percent on Thursday, were examples of large-stock rises which could buoy the market.
Analysts said top gainer Elektromontaz Export enjoyed a speculative 9.3-percent surge but may have also been helped by winning a $1.3 million contract on Wednesday.

They said biggest loser Prochnik, down 9.7 percent, fell in profit taking after its previous 7.3-percent jump. Mass privatisation NFI units fell 1.1 percent to 90 zlotys and fell 1.1 percent to 89 zlotys in continuous trade, where no stocks traded.
